data.title: Install-upgrade extension action is not user friendly and user can trigger same action multiple time

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
OS: WIndows10
App Version:

Steps: 
1. Launch an app and open ASP .net 5 C# project.
2. Update correct settings for the targeted runtime and SDK in project.json and global.json file.
3. Open any c# file and verify status bar for extension or run command >DNX run and verify status bar for extension.
4. Click on extension info icon in the status bar to get missing extension, it will launch a command palette to install extension.
![statusbarextensioninfo](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13731608/9d38e36e-e92a-11e5-89aa-d793826b11e0.png)
5. Install extension from command palette and wait for the completion.
6. Click again on the icon to upgrade extension and click on update icon from command palette.
7. Verify status bar and wait for completion.

Actual:
1. There is no pop-up about the extension installation\upgrade progress.
2. If user perform multiple action to upgrade same extension then upgrade progress is showing up  forever in the status bar.
3. It is showing the status of 'n' installation in status bar. Where 'n' is the number of times user performed upgrade action for same extension.
![extension-upgrade](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13731578/bf170408-e929-11e5-8490-8e3164210ff6.png)

Expected: 
1. Update icon should be disabled when installation is running in background.
![update-icon-enabledallthetime](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13731592/30d4d296-e92a-11e5-81ae-453dd858f82c.png)
1. User should not be able to trigger same action before completion of previous action.
2. User should get proper notification if he is performing same action. Like:
          a. Installation is in progress
          b. There is no update for this extension. or You have the latest version of extension already installed.

data.title: Editor Ruler doesn't cover additions to the file
data.body:
![brokenruler](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1016104/13730861/ff16c5ae-e931-11e5-8e44-9ba4780aada7.png)

To recreate:
1. Open a new file
2. Press <kbd>Enter</kbd> a bunch of times
3. Scroll down

This is on Ubuntu, I haven't tried it on any other platforms.

Switching to another file and back fixes it.
### Version

```
Version 0.10.10
Commit 5b5f4db87c10345b9d5c8d0bed745bcad4533135
Date 2016-03-07T10:30:20.458Z
Shell 0.35.6
Renderer 45.0.2454.85
Node 4.1.1
```

data.title: Intelli-sense accessibility
data.body:
- [x] win @dbaeumer 
- [x] mac @seanmcbreen  

Disclaimer: I only tested on Windows with NVDA, it is a Chromium bug that the editor text is silent on the Mac.
- We cannot use proper aria semantics due to a (Chromium bug)[https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=593646].
- When IntelliSense pops up, an alert tells the current focused suggestion.
- When picking suggestions, an alert tells the current focused suggestion.
- When accepting a suggestion, an alert tells that the suggestion was accepted.
- Known issue: the current line text is read again by NVDA when doing cursor down/up when picking suggestions.

data.title: Column select
data.body:
- [x] win @dbaeumer 
- [x] mac @bgashler1  
- [x] linux @weinand 
- Also try a readonly editor.
- Using the mouse: Similar to Shift+mouse drag, but use Shift+Alt+mouse drag to "draw" a rectangle.
- Using the keyboard: Ctrl/Cmd+Shift+Alt+arrow keys to "draw" a rectangle.
- You basically get multicursors at the intersection of the rectangle and the text.

data.title: Support npm auto detection

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hello,

It would be great to avoid creating or modifying a task in tasks.json file each time you update something.
I use nodejs with npm scripts in package.json (step1) and I need to create a task in tasks.json (step2) then add it in preLaunchTask (step3). I think step2 is not necessary in my case and I'm loosing time each time I update or create a new script in package.json.
So I think it would be necessary to avoid it when possible by specifying the tool needed in launch.json:

``` js
"preLaunchTaskProvider":"npm",
"preLaunchTask": "run mynpmscript"
```

The preLaunchTaskProvider could be npm, gulp, grunt, jake or vscode(tasks.json), even shell (npm run clean && npm run build) ...

I hope this could improve vscode and help others.

Thanks in advance for your comments.

data.title: Preview the changelog when looking for outdated extensions
data.body:
When you check for outdated extensions (`F1 / Extensions: Show Outdated Extensions`), you are able to see the `Readme` and `License`, but not `what's new` :cry: . 

Besides not being a required file when publishing extensions (in `package.json`), the `Changelog`  should be shown, if existed. Even better if it could show the difference from the installed and the new version, but for that, I know it would need _to define how changelog file is structured_).

Thanks in advance

data.title: Need user preferences for near-invisible widgets

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Bracket matching is nearly invisible (opacity: 0.1!) and secondary cursors are nearly as bad, and it's unclear whether these things are even themable. Whether they are or not, you shouldn't have to go searching for a whole different theme or learn to build your own themes just to make a basic widget usable.

You could start by just putting a few of these in the global preferences, ex:
Bracket matching style: [outline, underline, background]
Bracket matching color: [rgba()]
Secondary cursor width: [1px, 2px, 3px]
Secondary cursor color: [rgba()]

Just those two would be a great improvement, but an even nicer approach would be an additional user settings file (like Atom's "styles.cson") that offered a large selection of options for styling non-themable items and overriding individual settings in the current theme. Some things such as the subtle distinction between 2-shade highlighting schemes (ex: all found items vs. the one current found item) or the faint ghost outline used by some themes as the current line highlight are too subtle to see at a glance, even with good vision, and it would be great if we could make it easier for users to see comfortably (or distinguish shades of color) by simply filling in a few `style: [x | y | z]` or `color: [rgba]` settings in a "styles overide" file rather than requiring a time-consuming detour from your real work into research on the issue of what can be themed and how.

data.title: Incorrect rendering of key bindings with Spanish keyboard on linux
data.body:
According to the documentation, vscode renders the key bindings using the system keyboard layout. 
But in my case, the rendered key bindings do not seem to correspond to my layout. 

For instance, the split command is shown to be <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd></kbd>, however that combination toggles a line comment. 

The toggle line comment is shown to be <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>-</kbd>, but such combination reduces the font size.

The output of `localectl status` is:

``` text
   System Locale: LANG=es_ES.UTF-8
       VC Keymap: n/a
      X11 Layout: es
       X11 Model: pc102
     X11 Options: compose:ralt,terminate:ctrl_alt_bksp
```

data.title: Startup performance testing
data.body:
- [x] Any platform @bpasero

Use our performance tools to measure how we behave in startup times and where we can improve.
- time spent in main process
- time spend in renderer process
- time until plugin host is ready
- etc.

data.title: ES6 syntax highlight seems not working
'Project' management via extension?
data.body:
Is it possible to customise the project tree area via extension?
Let's imagine I wanted to write an MSBuild extension which would read a .sln and present solution/projects the same way VS does. Is this possible? What is required to get there?

There are other project systems that would be nice to support in the same way (a lot of IDE's can parse a makefile and populate a project from that), and it would be great if extensions had the power to populate the tree, and register some project-associated commands, like 'set active project', build and run.

data.title: Cursor placement using mouse on tab characters
data.body:
If you click on a tab in the editor window, the cursor is placed after the tab.
I'm using tabs=4 spaces, and that is quite large. I usually want to place the cursor before the tab, but that is quite hard to do, especially if the tab is for indentation at the start of the line.

Suggest, the cursor should be placed on the side of the tab that the mouse is closer to. It's not intuitive that clicking very close to the left hand side of the tab places the cursor at the right of the tab (quite a long way from the cursor). It's fiddly and I'm often making errors and typing/pasting in the wrong place.

data.title: Solarized color scheme does not correctly highlight certain keywords
data.body: vscode Atom: Sublime: I believe that the keywords const, export, private, and class should be darkgray as in sublime.

data.title: Better Support for ESNext
data.body:
At present, using ESNext features such as decorators, async/await, class instance fields, etc. results in the editor drawing red squiggles. In the very least, it would be nice if there was an easy way to stop VSCode from complaining about these features in a normal .js file.

Perhaps some thought needs to go into how VSCode will handle the evolution of ES in general. With developers using tools like Babel, and opting into stage-n features before they are finalized as a norm, I think this is going to crop up more and more. Not to mention that popular frameworks like Aurelia, React, Ember and Angular 2 are using these features more.

As for me, I have a hard time recommending VSCode to anyone that isn't doing TypeScript or sticking strictly to ES2015. It gets ugly pretty quick otherwise. I'm looking forward to seeing this improve. It's the only thing really holding me back. Thanks for all the great work so far!

data.title: Provide *.desktop file for help create an icon launcher easily in *Linux
data.body:
I tried create a *.desktop launcher, but didn't worked. I copied atom.desktop and replaced some strings, but it seems not bind with app code. Code from my *.desktop launcher:

```
[Desktop Entry]
Name=Visual Studio Code
Comment=Build and debug modern web and cloud applications.
GenericName=Visual Studio Code
Exec=/usr/share/code/code %U
Icon=/usr/share/code/resources/app/resources/linux/code.png
Type=Application
StartupNotify=true
Categories=GNOME;GTK;Utility;TextEditor;Development;
MimeType=text/plain;
```

data.title: fixes copyright compare on win when in crlf mode
Streamline extension recommendations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Towards the end of #3633 in a summary by @egamma, a design decision is listed that recommended extensions shouldn't be refreshed unless one of them was installed.

I could be misreading that thread or misunderstanding the desired behavior of the feature, but a month after opening a PHP file, I find myself staring at a bunch of PHP recommendations even though I'm into a project now that doesn't use PHP at all...making this feature useless.

Shouldn't this be based on whatever file you have open, like I believe it originally was?

data.title: Separate section for "errors and warning" output

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
See screenshots below; I use VCS for Golang development and after saving a file, the output goes into the "Errors and Warnings" section. However this is ONLY visible in the status bar on the bottom of the editor. I would like the output to be visible in a separate section of the screen. Is this possible now? Or is there some kind of extension which does this?

I know I can use `COMMAND + SHIFT + M` to open it, but I would like to have it visible directly after saving my file.

[edit]
Kind of related: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1135

![screen shot 2016-03-12 at 19 02 45](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3907131/13724459/c24dcbbe-e886-11e5-8641-96cb73e91b8f.png)

![screen shot 2016-03-12 at 19 02 59](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3907131/13724457/a611e106-e886-11e5-9195-95be0d1fded9.png)

data.title: Format Typescript info on symbol/error hover

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
We use type aliases in our code instead of classes and interfaces. For larger types it becomes almost impossible to make any sense of the text that Typescript outputs because it can be more lines than what fits on a small screen.

It would be more than awesome if the text displayed on hover would be parsed and formatted. Perhaps collapse large types and make it possible to expand them by clicking on them?

data.title: Errors detected while running the preLaunchTask on every task run
Test new folding actions
data.body:
**Issue:** #3580 
**Assignees:**
- [x] @alexandrudima 

**Details:**

  Ctrl + K, Ctrl + 1 : Folds all regions of level 1, except if a cursor is placed in it
  Ctrl + K, Ctrl + 2 : Folds all regions of level 2, except if a cursor is placed in it
...
  Ctrl + K, Ctrl + 5 : Folds all regions of level 5, except if a cursor is placed in it
